content: # Condensing Boiler Specific Fault Finding Guide
This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for components and issues specific to condensing boilers, including condensate systems, secondary heat exchangers, and efficiency-related faults.
- Boiler lockout with condensate or drain error code
- Water leaking from pressure relief valve
- Error codes specific to condensate system
- Examine condensate pipe for visible blockages
- Check for proper fall on external pipework (minimum 2.5° slope)
- Inspect for kinks, bends, or damage to pipework
- Verify trap is filled with water
- Look for signs of freezing in external sections
- Remove trap assembly according to manufacturer's guidance
- Check for debris, sludge, or blockages
- Verify correct reassembly with proper seals
- Ensure trap holds adequate water seal depth
- Test operation with small water volume
- Test flow capability with warm water
- Ensure no other appliances connect to condensate pipe
- Symptoms: Winter breakdowns, pipe visibly frozen
- Cause: External pipework exposed to freezing temperatures
* Short-term: Thaw with warm water, never boiling water
* Increase pipe diameter to 32mm for external runs
- Symptoms: Water backing up into boiler, error codes
- Cause: Debris accumulation, lack of maintenance
- Cause: Inadequate fall, excessive bends, improper termination
* Limit bends to bare minimum, use 45° rather than 90°
- Contains carbonic acid from CO₂ in flue gases
- Can damage copper, aluminum and some concrete materials
- Volume typically 2-3 liters per hour at full output
- Test with pH strips or digital meter
- Examine any metal components in contact with condensate
- Look for blue-green deposits (copper corrosion) or white powdery residue (aluminum corrosion)
- Check limestone chips or neutralizing media
- Verify flow is passing through neutralizer
- Test pH before and after neutralizer
- Check for bypassing or channeling through media
- Symptoms: Damaged drains, leaks at joins
- Cause: Long-term exposure to acidic condensate
- Symptoms: Premature failure of metal parts in contact with condensate
- Cause: Chemical attack from acidic condensate
* Ensure proper drainage to prevent pooling
- Symptoms: pH remains low after neutralizer
* Resize if flow rate exceeds capacity
- Higher flue gas temperature than specification
- Calculate delta T (should be typically 20°C at full load)
- Measure flue gas temperature (higher than spec indicates fouling)
- Check for soot accumulation on gas side
- Inspect for signs of corrosion or pinholes
- Measure fuel consumption versus heat output
- Compare current efficiency with commissioned values
- Verify proper condensing operation at lower loads
- Symptoms: Reduced heat transfer, high flue temperatures
- Cause: Hard water, inadequate water treatment
* System filter on return to boiler
- Cause: Incorrect air/gas ratio, poor combustion
- Cause: Condensate pooling, improper materials, low pH
- Sensitive to pH extremes in system water
- Test system water pH (should be 7.0-8.5 for aluminum)
- Look for signs of aluminum oxide (white powder)
- Test for other metals in system water
- Check for cold spots using thermal imaging
- Look for signs of deposition at low flow points
- Isolate and pressure test if leakage suspected
- Check for pressure loss over time
- Look for external signs of water/gas leakage
- Cause: Mixed metals in system without proper inhibitor
- Symptoms: Cracks at stress points, leakage
- Cause: Rapid temperature changes, poor flow
* Ensure minimum flow rates are maintained
* Consider low loss header for system protection
- Symptoms: Restricted flow, cold areas on exchanger
- Cause: Aluminum corrosion products depositing in narrow waterways
- Maximum efficiency achieved when return water below dew point (54-56°C)
- Control systems must manage flow temperatures appropriately
- Weather compensation critical for optimizing condensing
- High return temperatures prevent condensing and reduce efficiency
- Check for excessive flow rates (reducing delta T)
- Verify radiator sizing is appropriate for condensing
- Measure actual return temperatures during operation
- Assess minimum load capability without cycling
- Symptoms: High return temperatures, reduced efficiency
- Cause: Incorrect compensation curve, sensor issues
* Adjust compensation curve to lower flow temperatures
* Verify outdoor sensor location and operation
- Symptoms: Short cycling, high return temperatures
- Cause: Boiler capacity exceeds demand significantly
* Increase minimum modulation with buffer vessel
* Adjust boiler sequence for multiple boilers
* Consider replacement with properly sized unit
- Symptoms: High return temperatures despite controls
- Cause: Poor hydraulic separation, flow imbalance
- Modern condensing boilers typically modulate down to 20-30% of maximum
- Control systems vary gas and air rates to match demand
- Proper modulation critical for efficiency and component longevity
- Issues often relate to feedback sensors and control algorithms
- Observe actual modulation behavior under varying load
- Test gas pressure at different modulation rates
- Symptoms: Unstable operation, flame failure, noise changes
- Cause: Control issues, sensor problems, gas valve faults
- Symptoms: Unable to modulate properly, minimum too high
- Cause: Gas valve issues, incorrect settings, air/gas ratio
* Check for restrictions in air or gas supply
- Symptoms: Unexpected modulation behavior, error codes
- Cause: Firmware issues, board failure, wiring problems
* Reset to factory settings if possible
## PART 4: REFERENCE TABLES AND TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDES
| Condensate Production | 1.5-3 L/hour at full load | Significantly reduced or stopped |
| Trap Water Seal | Minimum 75mm | Below minimum, gurgling sounds |
| Pipe Fall | Minimum 2.5° continuous | Any sections with inadequate fall |
| Pipe Internal Diameter | 21.5mm minimum (3/4") | Below minimum, evidence of freezing |
| External Insulation | 13mm minimum | Inadequate, signs of freezing |
| Material | Cleaning Method | Inspection Points | Warning Signs |
| Aluminum | Aluminum-compatible cleaner | Oxide deposits, stress points | White powder, crystalline deposits |
| Stainless Steel | Stainless-compatible descaler | Weld joints, stress cracks | Brown staining, pitting |
| Cast Iron | Specific cast iron cleaner | Sections joints, internal surfaces | Orange deposits, section cracks |
| Copper | Copper-safe descaler | Brazed joints, flow paths | Blue-green deposits, erosion near joints |
| High Return Temperature | Reduced efficiency, less condensate | Measure return temp (should be <54°C) | Lower flow temp, balance system, check controls |
| Poor Condensing | Low condensate volume, high flue temp | Check flue gas/return water temps | Adjust flow temperature, verify hydraulic separation |
| Improper Modulation | Cycling, temperature swings | Monitor modulation behavior | Check sensors, update controls, verify gas valve |
| Heat Exchanger Fouling | Rising flue gas temp, reduced efficiency | Flue gas analysis, visual inspection | Clean heat exchanger, water treatment |
| System Oversizing | Short cycling, high return temps | Calculate load vs. boiler capacity | Adjust burner rate, modify controls, buffer vessel |
